properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow for a few more hours before coming to an end tonight. Storm total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm expected. Snow continues. A widespread 15 cm is anticipated, with up to 25 cm likely in areas under heavier bands of snow. Hazardous winter weather travel conditions will continue during this time. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-23T12:29:22-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. Sloppy mix of snow, ice pellets, and rain set to continue for a few more hours. Hazards: A sloppy mix of snow, ice pellets, and rain Quickly accumulating snow rates at times Impacts: Slippery road conditions Low visibility at times Timing: Now through 10 PM this evening Snow continues to mix with ice pellets and rain early this evening across southwestern Ontario. Precipitation is beginning to end west to east. Snow is generally most likely further away from Lake Erie. Motorists should continue to be prepared for winter weather driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-23T08:00:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-23T00:57:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0599327322.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected. A changeover to freezing rain will occur late in the night and continue through Monday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-23T15:09:31-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected over the Montreal Island tonight. Northern and eastern parts of Montreal could see a few hours of freezing precipitation late in the night and very early Monday morning. Travel conditions could be difficult Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected. The snow will be followed by a period of freezing rain late tonight and early Monday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy, tonight. Snow will continue tonight. However, as temperatures rise, the snow is forecast to transition to rain. A brief period of freezing rain may occur before temperatures rise above zero. By early Monday morning, the rain will transition to snow once again as temperatures fall. Snowfall accumulations in the 5 to 10 cm range are expected. Travel is expected to be impacted. Motorists should be prepared for winter weather driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain, and strong winds expected. Total snowfall: near 10 cm. Total rainfall: up to 25 mm, with the greatest amounts expected from Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 80 km/h on Tuesday becoming northwesterly up to 100 km/h Tuesday night. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to develop Monday evening before changing to rain, at times heavy, overnight Monday night. The rain will end during the day Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-23T18:12:37-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Locations: Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm, with highest amounts in the west and south. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h. Stronger coastal gusts possible. Time span: Monday night through Tuesday night. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds and rain will spread from west to east across the Island Monday night into Tuesday. The heaviest rainfall rates and amounts are expected over western and southern Newfoundland on Tuesday, and into Tuesday evening in the east. The rain will taper to flurries Tuesday night as strong northwesterly winds cause cooler temperatures to spread across the Island. Wind warnings have been issued for Channel-Port aux Basques to Corner Brook. Additional wind warnings along with rainfall warnings will likely be issued with subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-23T18:08:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-23T02:09:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3459032634.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions are occurring in Clyde River. A low pressure system over Davis Strait is bringing snow to the region along with strong northwesterly winds. Winds gusting at times to 70 km/h are bringing blizzard condition which will persist throughout the night. Conditions are expected to gradually improve Monday morning, ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-23T19:59:35-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 40 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 100 km/h or more. Locations: Labrador coast from Cartwright and vicinity to Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: Monday night until Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Monday evening and become heavy at times by Tuesday morning. Strong north to northwest winds will develop later on Tuesday and combined with the fresh snowfall will result in poor visibility in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Snowfall Monday night: 20 to 30 cm. Snowfall Tuesday: a further 30 to 40 cm possible. Maximum wind gusts: northerly up to 80 km/h on Tuesday. Locations: central Labrador including Upper Lake Melville. Time span: Monday evening and continuing until Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to develop Monday evening and continue through the day Tuesday. Strong northerly winds will develop early Tuesday resulting in widespread blowing snow. Conditions will improve late on Tuesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight. Snow, at times heavy, will continue into tonight. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected by the time the snow tapers off Monday morning. This heavy snow is due to a strengthening low pressure system that will track northeastward across the lower Great Lakes tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A deep low pressure system will approach over the Gulf of Alaska late Monday and combine with an Arctic ridge over the Northwest Territories to give rise to strong east winds of 60 km/h gusting to 80 near the Richardson Mountains. These strong winds will cause poor visibility in blowing snow and wind chill values near minus 25. Blizzard conditions will begin early Monday evening and then end overnight. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog has developed in the Whitecourt area, and is expected to persist into the late morning. The area of fog is expected to expand to the southeast and northwest throughout the night, so the fog advisory will likely be expanded. The fog is expected to lift near noon, but redevelop Monday evening. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 130 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: Monday night until midday Tuesday. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds will develop Monday night gusting to 100 km/h. Winds will strengthen throughout the overnight hours reaching peak gusts early Tuesday morning. Winds will ease upon shifting to westerly later on Tuesday. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Snow will begin Monday morning and end Tuesday morning. The snow may be briefly accompanied by freezing rain Monday afternoon. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight. Snow will continue tonight. 10 to 15 cm of accumulation will be possible before the snow tapers off early Monday morning. A brief period of freezing rain will also be possible tonight. Travel is expected to be impacted due to the heavy snow. Motorists should be prepared for winter weather driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
